course.subject: IELM
course.name: Integrated Production Systems
course.description: Basic concepts and techniques in design and operational control of integrated production systems, including MRP, JIT, forecasting, production planning, inventory control, and shop floor control and scheduling.
course.prerequisites: IELM 2510 AND IELM 3010
course.exclusions: ISOM 2700, ISOM 2720

reviews.author: vs
reviews.title: Probably my favorite course, content wise, thus far
reviews.comment_content: Operations management algos, lots of heuristics. Some interesting theory (as in the textbook), but much of the conceptual stuff isn't covered (which is the norm in IE courses). I found this course really interesting.
reviews.comment_teaching: She's thorough and very intelligent. Slightly awkward though, has some odd mannerisms, but not at all problematic. Can explain concepts clearly and convincingly, go to Terence the TA (harsh af grader) or raise hands and ask in class. She likes students that participate
reviews.comment_grading:
Homeworks are easy, so make sure you get full marks / near full on all of them. Go over each question twice, cross-check with a friend.

Midterm was really straightforward, i think at least a third of the class got nearly full marks. Again, heavily computation driven (i.e. they'll change the #s from the homework Qs and give them to you) - don't need to put thought into it, just grab your pen and hope you can finish on time. Cheat sheets allowed.

Final is pretty much non cumulative, but heavy focus on EOQ model (both types) - I think over half the paper was on this topic. Make sure to thoroughly go over this module in your revision. Final is around half of your overall grade

I managed to stay on course for an A up till the final, when I slipped to a B.
reviews.comment_workload:
Light - to average, depending on how attentive you are in class. I checked out the textbook and read the chapters, and did the Qs just to make sure I understood the core concepts -> doing this took a while, but the contents were just so dang interesting

On average, an assignment every ~10 days to be submitted in class.
